abstract.p: Michael O'Hanlon and Adekeye Adebajo letter responds to Nov 1 editorial on Clinton Administration's proposal for African peacekeeping force

block.p: ''An African Peace Force'' (editorial, Nov. 1) is right to support this initiative. You note the concerns expressed by President Nelson Mandela of South Africa about such a force. But President Mandela would do well to remember that fellow Africans like Ghana's first President, Kwame Nkrumah, and Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations pushed the idea of cooperative security efforts among Africans long before the United States ever did.

''An African Peace Force'' (editorial, Nov. 1) is right to support this initiative. You note the concerns expressed by President Nelson Mandela of South Africa about such a force. But President Mandela would do well to remember that fellow Africans like Ghana's first President, Kwame Nkrumah, and Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations pushed the idea of cooperative security efforts among Africans long before the United States ever did.
Most important, discretion would be advised in any decision to use the force.

Some tasks would be beyond its competence, requiring more troops or advanced military hardware than contributing units are likely to possess. For example, such a force might have been able to feed starving masses in Somalia but would not have been up to the challenge of defeating the Somali faction leader, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid. It could have improved the effectiveness of the West African intervention force, Ecomog, in Liberia, but would not itself have been able to create a new government there. But if used to protect safe havens and relief operations, it could indeed be helpful.
MICHAEL O'HANLON ADEKEYE ADEBAJO Washington, Nov. 1, 1996
The writers are, respectively, a military analyst and a research fellow at the Brookings Institution.
